ratings.comment: Took multiple of his ethics classes, with only positive experiences. Definitely cares about students and will give great feedback. As with most profs, going to office hours / participating in class will get you more out of these experiences. 10/10 would recommend, I would have taken more of his classes if I could.

Prof. Streiffer is a great teacher and he is very knowledgeable about the material in the course. Lectures are more or less open discussions and there is a lot of reading. He provides a number of topics for each of the papers that are assigned so that there should be at least one that sparks some interest. Overall a great professor!

Prof. Streiffer makes this class great because of the excitement that he obviously has for the subjects. Lectures are more like open discussions with the whole class, and enjoyable. The shortfall is the pop quizzes, which ask ab specific details in 20+ pages of heavy reading, but they don't account for that much grade-wise.

The way in which this class is organized and taught is exceptional. I have learned an incredible amount about the ethics of healthcare by taking Med Hist 558 and it has truly been an eye-opening experience to many subjects that I have always wondered about. Truly an excellent class with an excellent professor and T.A. Would undoubtedly recommend.

Professor Streiffer is one of my favorite professors in Madison. He's very helpful and knowledgeable, and very clear in his lectures. Workload is reasonable. Readings can be long occasionally, but it's easy to scan through them.

The pop-quizzes given on the 50 pages of reading for every class are nigh-impossible. Takes forever to grade papers. He's quite a good lecturer when he isn't reading off the slides (which isn't often). You'll do fine if you've taken prior philosophy courses (101, 341) and/or courses dealing with remedial genetics (Bio 101/151).

Do not take modern ethical theory with Professor Streiffer. He overloads the reading schedule and then ends up rushing through important material while also omitting certain readings. The "random" quizzes are difficult, even when you have done the reading. And, his comments on papers is worthless. I expected more from him and the course.

Great professor - he knows the material like the back of his hand and takes the time to make sure you fully understand it as well. No tests, just 4 papers. Read articles in the course reader, got to class and work with your TA and you shouldn't have a problem. It's not an easy class but if you work at it, you can definitely do well.

He made discussion interesting, and tried to incorporate all views on animal bioethics. No tests, only papers and occasional pop quizzes on the readings. The readings are extremely long and wordy, making the quizzes difficult regardless of whether you read. Overall a good class, though.

This was a trial run for an Animal Bioethics course. He was a little sloppy and unorganized, but super, super nice and helpful. The Philosophy part was confusing, but if you ask him for help, the papers became a lot easier. Readings were ridiculous, though.

Great Phil teacher.  Love his examples and the way he uses them to help explain the material.  However reading the material is needed for the best understanding.  Overall Good Prof and I recommend him for any Phil class.
No tests, only papers, which is nice.  Lecture is boring, and attendance is a large part of your grade.  Yet, attending lecture guarantees a grade boost.  Difficult for non-philosophy majors.
Very helpful outside of class and a stickler for rigor - both good things.
